Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates by stating that a federal court ordered former President Barack Obama to pay "$400 million in restitution," when in fact, multiple sites have carried the fictitious story and there is no truth to it.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as there are no actual federal courts or judges mentioned in the stories that supposedly ordered Obama to pay the restitution.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that Obama was involved in an illegal transaction with Iranian hard-liners and that the court ordered him to repay $400 million for the funds that were "lost." However, there is no evidence or factual basis to support this assumption.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the $400 million payment to Iran in 2016 was not claimed to be "lost" by the Obama White House, as stated in the specialnewsusa.com story.
Understate: There is no understatement bias present in the claim.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by presenting false information and misleading readers into believing that Obama was ordered to pay the restitution, when in reality, it is a fictitious story.
Exist alternative explanation: There is no alternative explanation bias present in the claim as it is purely based on false information and misinformation.
